clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Topical and Nebulized Anesthesia in Patients Undergoing Esophago-Gastro-Duodenoscopy
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Topical and Nebulized Anesthesia in Patients Undergoing Esophago-Gastro-Duodenoscopy

brief_summary.textblock: This study compares the effect of nebulized lidocaine and lidocaine spray in patients undergoing esophago-gastro-duodenoscopy. The investigators evaluate the success rate of the procedure between two methods.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a randomized-controlled trial in the patients undergoing esophago-gastro-duodenoscopy. The patients are randomized by computer into two arms: nebulized lidocaine and lidocaine spray. Both drugs are applied 15-20 minutes prior the prior the procedure. Only one endoscopist participate in this study. After the procedure finishes, the investigators evaluate the outcome and satisfaction of patients and endoscopist.

primary_outcome.measure: Comparison of Topical and Nebulized Anesthesia
primary_outcome.description: Both nurse anesthetist and endoscopist evaluate difficulty during the procedure and demand for additional sedative drugs using numeric scale

secondary_outcome.description: Satisfaction is evaluated using Numeric Rating Scale (0-10)
Satisfaction is evaluated using Numeric Rating Scale (0-10)

intervention.description: 5 puffs of 10% Lidocaine spray is administered every 5 minutes for 4 times. Then the patient is undergone procedure 5 minutes later.
The patient receives 2.5 mL of 10% lidocaine is used by nebulizer under oxygen flow 6-7 LPM for 15 minutes prior the procedure.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- elective case for esophago-gastro-duodenoscopy with ASA classification 1-2
- Both genders
- Age between 18-65 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of smoking
- Upper respiratory tract infection
- Asthma
- Heart disease
- Allergy to local anesthetic drugs
Withdrawal or termination criteria
- Patient refusal
- Patient develops lidocaine allergy
- Bronchospasm
- Sign of Local Anesthetic Toxicity
